conversation.message: [APPLY] School_C is one of my top choices, and I’m ready to commit immediately. If accepted, I will enroll and withdraw from consideration elsewhere. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_B, but School_B’s priority ranks me 4th (behind Student_E, Student_B, Student_C). Since everyone knows preferences, those higher-priority students are likely to apply there immediately, so an [APPLY] now is very likely to be rejected and wastes the round. My next choice is School_C, where I am ranked 3rd (behind Student_B and Student_C). Student_B’s first choice is School_A, so they may not apply to School_C early; Student_C’s second choice is School_C, but their first is School_B, so they may also start at School_B. That creates a realistic chance School_C can accept me in round 1 if I apply. Getting School_C (my #2) is better than risking rejection at School_B and then being pushed further down my list later.

conversation.message: Student_D, thank you for your application and your clear commitment. We’re pleased to offer you admission to School_C. Please confirm that you will enroll and withdraw from other schools as stated so we can finalize your seat. [ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: As School_C, my true priority order is B > C > D > E > A. Student_D is my 3rd choice and has submitted a binding-style commitment to enroll if accepted. In the broader market, Student_B ranks School_C 3rd (after A and B) and Student_C ranks School_C 2nd (after B), so there is a meaningful chance a higher-priority student could apply in later rounds. However, Student_D also ranks School_C 2nd and is applying now, which provides immediate certainty for filling my single seat with a relatively high-priority candidate. Student_A is lower on my list and only initiated TALK. Given the quota is 1 and Student_D is within my top tier (3rd) with strong commitment, I will accept now rather than risk ending unmatched or with a lower-priority student.

conversation.message: Hello School_C admissions team—I'm Student_A. School_C is one of my top choices, and I’m very interested in your academic environment and expectations. Could you share what you prioritize most in incoming students (e.g., academics, activities, fit) and what a successful first-year student at School_C typically looks like? I’d love to understand how to best present my strengths and commitment to School_C.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_B, but I have the lowest priority there, so an early [APPLY] is likely to be rejected if higher-priority students apply. School_C is my second choice and I also have the lowest priority there, but I can still try to position myself as a serious, committed candidate and learn what they value. Using [TALK] keeps me in the conversation without triggering an immediate rejection, while signaling strong interest and gathering info to tailor a later application if timing becomes favorable.

conversation.message:
Hello Student_A—thank you for reaching out and for your interest in School_C.

In incoming students, we prioritize:
- Strong academic readiness (especially consistent performance in core subjects and comfort with a rigorous pace)
- Intellectual curiosity and a clear sense of purpose (why you want our program specifically)
- Reliability and follow-through (meeting commitments, steady effort over time)
- Positive contribution to the community (collaboration, respect, and initiative in clubs/teams/projects)

A successful first-year student at School_C typically manages time well, seeks help early, participates in at least one sustained activity, and takes ownership of learning (asking good questions, revising work, and engaging in discussion).

At the moment, our seat is currently filled, so I can’t invite an application for immediate placement. If you’d like, tell me briefly (1) which subjects you’re strongest in, (2) one activity or project you’ve stuck with over time, and (3) what specifically about School_C makes it a top choice—so we understand your fit should circumstances change.

[TALK]
conversation.thought: My quota is already filled (0 remaining) due to an accepted match with Student_D this round. Student_A is initiating a [TALK], not an [APPLY], so I can respond conversationally. On my true priority list, Student_A is lowest; even if capacity reopened later, I would prefer higher-ranked students (B, C, D, E) first. Given current capacity, I should be transparent that we are currently full while still answering their questions and inviting them to share fit/strengths in case circumstances change.

conversation.message: Hello School_A admissions team—I'm Student_E. I’m very interested in joining School_A and believe I would be a strong fit for your program and community. I’m ready to commit if offered a seat. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_C, but School_C ranks me 4th (behind B, C, D). If I apply there immediately, I risk being rejected if higher-priority students apply. School_A ranks me 1st, and it is still high on my true list (3rd). Securing School_A now with an [APPLY] should lock in a strong outcome and remove uncertainty. Since matches are final upon acceptance, this is a safe strategy to guarantee a good placement rather than gamble on School_C.

Student_B is ranked higher than Student_C on my list, so accepting Student_C now would block a better match. Student_B also indicates willingness to commit, so I should preserve capacity for Student_B. Therefore I reject Student_C this round.
